skill.name: diffdock
skill.description: Diffusion-based molecular docking. Predict protein-ligand binding poses from PDB/SMILES, confidence scores, virtual screening, for structure-based drug design. Not for affinity prediction.
skill.summary: Diffusion-based molecular docking. Predict protein-ligand binding poses from PDB/SMILES, confidence ...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: The static analysis flagged numerous false positives from documentation files containing bash command examples. No actual security vulnerabilities were found in the executable code. The skill is a legitimate scientific tool for molecular docking research.

content.user_title: Predict molecular binding poses with AI docking
content.value_statement: DiffDock revolutionizes molecular docking by using diffusion models to predict how small molecules bind to proteins. Researchers can accelerate drug discovery by generating accurate 3D binding poses with confidence scores.
actual_capabilities: Predict 3D binding poses from PDB files and SMILES strings
Generate confidence scores for docking predictions
Support protein sequences via ESMFold integration
limitations: Predicts binding poses, not binding affinity

use_cases.title: Virtual screening campaigns
use_cases.description: Screen thousands of compounds against target proteins to identify potential drug candidates

use_cases.title: Binding site identification
use_cases.description: Predict where small molecules bind to protein structures for mechanistic studies

use_cases.title: Lead optimization
use_cases.description: Generate binding poses for compound modifications to improve binding interactions

prompt_templates.title: Basic docking
prompt_templates.scenario: Dock a ligand to a protein
prompt_templates.prompt: Dock the ligand COc1ccc(C(=O)Nc2ccccc2)cc1 to the protein in protein.pdb and save results to results/docking/

prompt_templates.title: Batch screening
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a batch CSV for screening 50 compounds against protein.pdb, then run DiffDock with 20 samples per complex

prompt_templates.title: Analyze results
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze the confidence scores from my DiffDock results in results/batch/ and show the top 10 predictions

prompt_templates.title: Custom parameters
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a custom config for docking flexible ligands with increased temperature and 30 inference steps, then dock ligand.sdf to protein.pdb

output_examples.input: Dock aspirin to COX-2 protein and analyze results
output: Generated 10 binding poses for aspirin-COX-2 complex
Binding site: Active site cavity near residues Arg120, Tyr355
Recommended: Visualize pose and validate with molecular dynamics

best_practices: Always validate environment with setup_check.py before large jobs
Use 20-40 samples per complex for critical predictions
Combine with scoring functions like GNINA for affinity estimation
Visualize top 3-5 poses to check for structural plausibility
anti_patterns: Using confidence scores as binding affinity predictions
Running without GPU for large virtual screening campaigns
Assuming single prediction is correct without examining alternatives
Ignoring protein preparation and missing residue issues

faq.question: What's the difference between confidence and affinity?
faq.answer: Confidence measures model certainty about the pose prediction, while affinity measures binding strength. High confidence doesn't mean strong binding.

faq.question: How many samples should I generate?
faq.answer: Use 10 for quick screening, 20-40 for important predictions, and 40+ for very flexible or large ligands.

faq.question: Can I use protein sequences instead of PDB files?
faq.answer: Yes, DiffDock uses ESMFold to predict protein structure from sequence, though PDB files give better results.

faq.question: What ligand formats are supported?
faq.answer: SMILES strings, SDF files, and MOL2 files. SMILES are most convenient for virtual screening.

faq.question: How do I interpret negative confidence scores?
faq.answer: Scores below -1.5 indicate low confidence. Consider more samples, ensemble docking, or experimental validation.

faq.question: Can DiffDock predict binding affinity?
faq.answer: No, DiffDock only predicts binding poses. Use GNINA, MM/GBSA, or experimental methods for affinity.
